channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Car Country, Obama Trumpets China Trade Case
item.description: President Obama on Monday filed a broad new trade case against China at the World Trade Organization. He announced the action in the industrial battleground of Ohio.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama announced a trade case against China on Monday in Cincinnati. Aides have defended the timing, with the election two months away.

item.title: Trial Begins of Police Chief in Bo Xilai Scandal
item.description: Wang Lijun, a key player in the fall of the politician Bo Xilai, tried to seek refuge in a United States Consulate, igniting the country’s biggest political scandal in a generation.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Mr. Wang, once close to the outcast Bo Xilai, in January.

item.title: At War Blog: Report Faults Military's Strategies on Drug and Alcohol Abuse
item.description: Despite a well-documented increase in the abuse of alcohol and prescription medications among military personnel over the past decade, the Defense Department's strategies for screening, treating and preventing remains behind the times, a major new report finds.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JAMES DAO

item.title: News Analysis: U.S. Files Trade Case Against China Over Cars
item.description: The case against China on cars and auto parts will have little immediate impact, but it is one of the few legal options available.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Workers assemble cars at Beijing Automotive Group factory in Zhuzhou, China.

item.title: Ketrzyn Journal: Restoring the Walls, and History, at a Hitler Command Post
item.description: The Polish government has decided that the Wolf’s Lair, the outpost where Hitler commanded the Third Reich for years, holds valuable history lessons that need to be preserved.
item.dc:creator: By JOANNA BERENDT
item.media:description: The Wolf's Lair, a 200-building encampment in the Polish forest from which Hitler, seen there on July 15, 1944, gave commands, fell into disrepair after the war.

item.title: In Greece, Restlessness Amid a Push for Cuts
item.description: Protests and strikes are gaining steam as Prime Minister Antonis Samaras renews efforts to come up with a tough new 11.5 billion euro austerity package.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Greek judges gathered at the Supreme Court on Monday. Some judges, joining doctors and transit workers, went on strike.

item.title: Israeli Diplomat Michael Oren Is Man in Middle
item.description: Ambassador Michael B. Oren, who happens to have been born and bred in New Jersey, is representing a prime minister who has infuriated the White House.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH BUMILLER
item.media:description: “Part of our responsibility is seeking to avoid war. And if we can avoid war by raising international consciousness about the nature of the Iranian threat, then we’re fulfilling our responsibility," said Michael B. Oren.

item.title: Possible Breakthrough in Math’s ABC Conjecture
item.description: A Japanese mathematician has released 500 pages of work on a problem known as the abc conjecture. Other mathematicians are excited, but bewildered by the proof.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG

item.title: India Ink: Why Kashmiri Muslims Blame America for Anti-Muslim Film
item.description: Kashmiri protestors and Islamic leaders on recent hate for the United States.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Muslim women at a protest against the movie “Innocence of Muslims,” made in the United States, which they allege ridicules Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: New Demotic Dictionary Translates Lives of Ancient Egyptians
item.description: The first dictionary of Demotic Egyptian, the language common people spoke in ancient Egypt while the pharaohs were drawing their hieroglyphics, has just been completed.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD
item.media:description: : A Demotic Egyptian writing sample at the University of Chicago's Oriental Institute.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza: Hamas Court Convicts 4 in Murder of Activist
item.description: A Hamas military court on Monday convicted four Palestinians of taking part in the 2011 kidnapping and killing of a pro-Palestinian Italian activist in the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: U.S.-Japan Missile Defense Accord Is Criticized in China
item.description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta arrived in China in the wake of a major missile defense agreement and amid tensions between China and Japan over disputed islands.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta with China’s defense minister, Liang Guanglie.

item.title: European Plan to Put More Women on Boards Runs Into Opposition
item.description: Legislation to impose sanctions on companies that do not allocate 40 percent of the seats on their boards to women may be blocked before it is officially proposed.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Viviane Reding, vice president of the European Commission, has championed the proposal.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Police Officer Fired Over Vendor’s Death
item.description: A British police officer was found guilty of gross misconduct and fired from the London force over actions that resulted in the death of a man during a Group of 20 summit meeting in 2009.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Bahrain: 7 Officers Charged Over Claims of Abuse
item.description: Bahrain said Monday that it had charged seven police lieutenants in connection with claims of abuse against people arrested during antigovernment protests last year.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Reports Sharp Jump in Attacks on Syrian Civilians
item.description: United Nations investigators said Monday they have “a formidable and extraordinary body of evidence” against those responsible for an increase in government attacks on civilians.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Syrian soldiers stood outside a damaged research facility after clashes with Free Syrian Army fighters in Aleppo on Monday.

item.title: Protests Over Contentious Film Spread to Afghanistan
item.description: Hundreds of Afghans burned tires and pelted police on Monday in Afghanistan’s first significant spasm of violence over an anti-Islam film that has inflamed parts of the Muslim world.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and SANGAR RAHIMI

item.title: Palestinian Authority’s Stability Threatened by Financial Strains
item.description: As the Palestinian Authority marks the 19th anniversary of the signing of the Oslo Accords, it is facing a financial crisis that experts say could threaten its future operations and stability.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Palestinians in Ramallah protesting the cost of living. Austerity and price increases have prompted outrage.

item.title: Myanmar Frees Prisoners as Thein Sein Prepares for U.N. Visit
item.description: The government said it had released 514 prisoners, many of whom were reported to have been political prisoners.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Iran Scientist Says Blasts Targeted Nuclear Sites
item.description: Iran’s top atomic energy official said that explosions were intended to cut power to two uranium enrichment facilities and claimed saboteurs had infiltrated an international inspection agency.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Japanese Companies Close Facilities in China as Tensions Rise
item.description: The dispute between Japan and China, over a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea, has led to violent attacks on factories, shops and even cars of well-known Japanese brands.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Workers at a Japanese restaurant in Beijing covered it with Chinese flags and red clothes ahead of an expected protest.

item.title: Thai Truth Commission Warns of Simmering Conflicts
item.description: A panel investigating deadly protests in 2010 that left more than 90 dead blamed the powerful Thai military and a shadowy group of militants, the black shirts.
item.dc:creator: By POYPITI AMATATHAM and THOMAS FULLER

item.title: In India, Mamata Banerjee May Bring Down Coalition
item.description: Mamata Banerjee, the chief minister of West Bengal, is praised and maligned in equal measure. But Indians agree that she has the ability to bring down India’s governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Mamata Banerjee, the head of the West Bengal State, in April.

item.title: U.S. Warns Judge’s Ruling Impedes Its Detention Powers
item.description: The government said the ruling last week has jeopardized its ability to detain certain prisoners captured in Afghanistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Czechs Ban Hard Liquor Sales After Methanol Poisonings
item.description: The Czech Republic has banned the sale of liquor containing 20 percent or higher alcohol content after at least 20 people were killed from consuming methanol-tainted spirits.
item.dc:creator: By DINAH SPRITZER and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A bartender in Prague on Friday covered up bottles of drinks containing more than 20 percent alcohol, in compliance with a recent government ban.
